title: Meh
review:
The one thing I have to say about this movie is they sacrificed vocal talent for big Hollywood names. Emma Watson's portrayal of Belle, the leading heroine, was awful. Her vocals were mediocre at best and I felt as if she portrayed Belle a bit to soft and not as the sassy "I can take care of myself" girl we saw in the 1991 movie. Don't even get me started on Luke Evans. His portrayal of Gaston was atrocious. I really would have liked to see some better, bigger voices in this movie.

Even with the mediocre voices and acting this film is visually stunning. The color palletes they chose were beautiful and the CGI was incredible.

Would I recommended this movie? Yes and no. If you have seen the 1991 version, then don't waste your time. If you haven't seen the 1991 version then go for it. I promise you will enjoy the animated version much more.

title: Stay True To the Original About
review:
Sure it will never compare to the original animation. But they sure did true. As really it added just some extra scenes to describe the back character of the stories.

Like that of Belle and Maurice and her late mom and his wife respectively. And why the Beast is the way he is. Which I love back stories to why they are.

But for those that complained about it never being the original. As really the manage the producers in keeping the story as authentic to the original.

Emma Watson makes a great Belle and Kevin Kline as her father. Have great chemistry and click well. Though Kline is taller than the cartoon Maurice.

Dan Stevens of Downton Abby as the troubled and foul mood Prince turned Beast. As beneath his tough exterior, lies a broken heart that melts away due to Watson.

Luke Evans as Gaston the handsome but mean spirited bully and bad guy of the film. Josh Gad as his lovable sidekick LeFou (However you spell it), that gets no love in return from his "friend".

Rest of the supporting cast of Ewan McGregor as lovable Lumiere, Ian McKellan as Clogsworth, and Emma Thompson as Mr Potts. As the candle, clock, and tea pot respectively help out the young cast.

Cute movie and about stays true to the original.

title: Well good made
review: I thought Beauty and the Beast was a great movie, well good made. It definitely had similarities to the original Beauty and the Beast cartoon in 1991. There were scenes that weren't in the original so that it could make the whole story longer to the live-action remake. The CGI to the castle objects were outstanding considering the movie was filmed in 2015 and took a year to make the CGI for the castle objects. The casting was perfect; Emma Watson did an amazing job as Belle and sung beautifully, Dan Stevens did well as the Beast, Luke Evans of course was superb as Gaston never expected to sing good, and everyone else who are the castle objects did awesome. Disney did an astounding job making a live-action remake, looking forward to their other remakes such as Mulan.

title: Beautiful!
review: Loved this film! It was gorgeous to look at - production design, sets, costumes. The music was wonderful, the direction excellent, everyone in it was excellent. I'm also a fan of the original; one of the things I liked about this version is how faithful the characterization was to the source work. Very enjoyable and well worth the time and money.

title: Interesting even though I anticipated boring...
review:
I went to watch this with my wife and daughter, thinking I would sit there for 2 hours twiddling my thumbs in utter boredom. The start fell right into my idea of the movie. A boring fairy tale with singing the whole movie through. It changed though. As soon as the first person entered the castle and then when Emma entered the castle things started to becoming really interesting. I personally LOVED the clock and the Candelebra. Done extremely well with a lot of laughter through the movie. The beast was done extremely well to me. Reading some of the comments just brought me back to the idea that there are many sourpusses that really just go to watch a movie to try and ridicule it and look for flaws. I bet there lives are really colorful. Emma played her part extremely well.

Watch this. Not a movie to be missed.

title: A remake of the Disney original Beauty and the Beast.
review: I am a total and complete fan of the original princess movies from Disney and I was completely ecstatic to know that they were remaking another classic to bring it back for the newer generations though I was almost expecting them to change the plot as they had with Malefica. However, I must say that I was not disappointed in any way. I loved watching as my kids eyes lit up as they followed the plot with what I can only say was the same enthusiasm I had when watching it so many years ago. I am not ashamed to say as well that I too watched with a renowned enthusiasm. I highly suggest that the Disney-loving parents take their children to see this movie as they will not be disappointed. I also suggest the opposition to learn to look into the value of the message and to take their children to see it as well. Who knows, maybe they will learn to love Disney again. Be our guest.

title: Nicely done!
review: There are differences in this version from the cartoon, however, I thought the movie was nicely done! Singing was great - left me with chills (in a good way). Some new songs were added in, but were nicely performed. Emma Watson made a beautiful Belle. I would definitely see it again!

title: The movie had a lot of added parts from the cartoon
review:
I really enjoyed the movie the roles were played well by the actors and actresses and i don't think they could have done any better.

I would definitely Bring the whole family to see the Movie All the animated characters were well animated and the live action character mixed well with the animated and had just the right mix of action and romance Im a 14 boy and i really liked the movie!!

title: A brilliant revisit to a beautiful tale from our childhoods
review:
I didn't have any expectations for this film due to the overwhelming disappointment I felt with the previous live action adaptations of Cinderella and The Jungle Book. It was due to this that I didn't expect to like this film. I was, however, pleasantly surprised.

For a start, this film fixes nonsensical aspects of the original which was a fantastic starting point – the original was never perfect so it made sense to remake it in order to fix these imperfections. The entire story makes more sense with the prince no longer being an eleven-year-old when cursed; there being an explained reason for the servants also being cursed; the fact that no one remembers the castle's existence; etc. There was also a more solid reason for the prince being cursed since the audience didn't really see much justification in the original as there were few examples of his selfishness.

The curse also comes across as more dark with the servants all slowly losing their humanity as time goes on and being rendered inanimate objects by the time all the petals have fallen. This introduction of actual consequences gives an insight to the desperation of the cursed characters as we can see how this factor leaks into their actions as motivation, giving them more depth. It also has an emotional impact on the audience when they resign themselves to their fate at the end of the film. It also evokes empathy for the Beast who not only has his own fate on his hands but the fate of everyone else in the castle – this makes his bitterness and anger towards the beginning of the film even more understandable due to guilt rather than just self-hate due to his appearance as in the original. The original used this aspect to show that Belle was making the Beast a better person, teaching him to stop caring for his looks and be kind, but I still preferred the remake here. Each film shows a different perspective of Beast and his motivations (the same can be said for the servants) which is something I love.

Another great aspect would be the changes made to characters. Unlike the original, there isn't a single character who I felt was pointless or underdeveloped. For example, Maurice who was portrayed as merely a bumbling inventor in the animation had far more depth and didn't act like an idiot. I could also see the bond between him and Belle better. Gaston also changed for the better, seeming more like an actual villain. He was truly driven by his motivations whereas he didn't seem particularly so in the original so I was never truly convinced of him as an evil character. Other than this, he actually did come across as evil due to his actions more so than the original. As for Belle, I enjoyed her character more as well as the effort they put into her backstory. I love how they made her an inventor and showed she was a truly capable and intelligent woman being held back by society at the time.

The most brilliant change to characters, however, was to LeFou. He was so much better than in the original for the fact he actually had a trait other than just being Gaston's sidekick and you could understand the motivations behind his actions also. I love how LeFou doesn't just follow along with what Gaston says with seemingly no reason and has an actual mind of his own in that he has morals and feels guilty for what he helped Gaston do to Maurice. The fact that LeFou seems to be in love with Gaston gives the audience a whole new level of understanding for his character as it's clear he is torn between what he believes is right and keeping the man he loves content and it shows he isn't simply an evil character like in the animation but a human being who is swayed by his emotions. The film also allowed his character redemption because, in the end, he was being used and manipulated by Gaston through his feelings for him which caused him to be 'evil'. I like the parallels which can be drawn between the Beast's curse and LeFou's love for Gaston – both made them 'monsters' but there is more to them than simply what is shown on the surface; there is good to them.

What I liked most about this film is how it remained faithful to the original, but different in all the best ways. Other than this, the new music was absolutely beautiful and somewhat reminded me of The Phantom of the Opera which I loved.

Some scenes just didn't need to exist though such as where Belle visits Paris – I understand what they were trying to do, but that information could have been delivered differently as the scene just feels out of place (as much as I love the song). The CGI was also somewhat odd and could have been done better.

You'd think they'd be able to hear how bad the tuning is on many of the songs. Watson's vocals were overly auto-tuned as if they were trying to make her sound more like the original Belle and couldn't. Almost every character had their vocals overly tuned at some point in the soundtrack rendering it difficult to listen to. Some tracks are done well, but the mixing and tuning in general just... leaves a lot to be desired. The vocal layering wasn't always mixed well either so it was difficult to hear each part.

As for Watson, she was the weakest link. She had some scenes where she was amazing and other scenes where she just seemed empty in her words and actions, like she didn't truly believe them herself. I wish they had cast a stronger actress and singer for this role since I felt there was something missing from her performance.

title: Deserves all the accolades and more....!
review: I'd been waiting for this movie for nearly an year ever since the first trailer came out, and I finally got to see it the way it deserved to be seen, seated in a plush, velvety, reclining couch, in my city's best "Royal Cinema" in 3-D. The animated original is a childhood classic of mine; I know all the songs and nearly all the scenes by heart. Going by the trailer, and learning about all the preparation that had gone in to its making, I was expecting it to be a grand affair, and it was just that, AND MORE.....! Everything from the luxurious sets, to the lavish costumes, the splendid dancing and the mesmerizing songs at once transported you to another world. I felt like I was watching a grand re-enactment of a Broadway musical and not a live- action version of a Disney animation. I kid you not when I say that I had the silliest grin plastered across my face every time a familiar song number came on, as I knew all the lyrics and every time an usher saw me singing along to the tune, they thought I was beckoning them to order food service. I believe Luke Evans a.k.a Gaston deserves a special mention; his role was strong and he portrayed it perfectly. Kevin Kline's contribution was limited. It's a shame we didn't get to see Emma Thompson (Mrs. Potts) and Ian McKellen (Mr. Cogsworth) spend much time on screen in their human forms but their household crockery/furniture versions were also effectively entertaining (especially Ewan McGregor as Lumiere). I have to admit, I wasn't completely sold on Emma Watson playing Bella as I felt she lacked the natural charm to portray Bella as a personable character and I'm afraid she did fall rather short in the beginning but I confess she'd won me over by the end and she and Dan Stevens made a lovely couple. I could tell they had put in considerable effort to master the dance moves in the ballroom scenes which were elevated to an ethereal level with their elegant outfits, the timeless music and their effortless gliding across the ballroom floor. All in all, it was a truly magical film as is the trademark of most Disney productions and I recommend all mothers take their daughters to see this film and share this amazingly delightful experience.

title: Nice adaptation of Disney animation
review: It is really beautiful and nice adaptation of one of my favorite Disney animations. Very colorful and relaxing. Although I struggle to watch Watson in role of Belle. Wasn't anyone better? She was OK in total, but she just doesn't look like beautiful Belle. On other part Stevens really surprised me, he was just copy of Adam.

title: Don't believe the negativity
review:
So, I have a bit to say. Some is about the movie, but most is about the horrible reviews it has been getting.

I'll start with my opinion of it: I really enjoyed it. It was fun and full of heart, like the original; not perfect, but what is? The misfires for me came in two places: Emma Watson as Belle and the ballroom scene. Emma Watson is a fine actress, but I've always felt that her range was a bit small. Her reactions to Gaston's advances at the beginning of the movie are pretty much the same as her reactions to him shooting the Beast at the end. That shouldn't be the case. And the ballroom scene... We'll, the camera work and direction just felt lacking because of the fantastic work of the original.

However, that brings me to my main thrust: all of the 1-3 star reviews here. Why? Well, after about 5 or so hours of reading, I've boiled it down to a few common threads: perception of Emma's singing, the Beast's CGI, and the lack of that ever elusive "charm" or "spirit" of the original. Firstly, there are a lot of people crying "Autotune! Emma's been Autotuned cause she can't sing!!" I'm not going to claim to be an expert on Autotune. However, I have been around great singers my whole life, and I'll say this: if she was Autotuned, it was slight. Her performance sounds like an above average (but not great) singer whose vocal coach focuses on polish over emotion in the performance. Second, the Beast's CGI was just like Shere Khan's in Jungle Book: magnificent and detailed, with an emphasis on movement of hair and moisture on it. Lastly, lack of "charm." I thought I understood that, but when people started talking about Bill Murray having "charm," I was lost. Then I realized: "charm" is subjective, unquantifiable, and is often informed by predetermined bias; in other words, if you go looking for "charm," you'll find it where you want to, and nowhere else.

All of this, however, boils down even further to one shining ray of truth: 90s kids think that their generation was the peak of culture, and that art, music, and culture is just going downhill. That belief leads them to look at the 1991 movie (which was fantastic) as the gold- standard that they have an interest in maintaining. So, nothing will be as good as it was; if this one is, then movies are getting better, not worse, and their time wasn't the peak of culture.

Tl;Dr: Ignore the 1-3 star reviews, this movie was fan-freaking-tastic and definitely worth the watch.

title: Only 'True Love' can break the spell.
review:
'Beauty and the Beast' is Disney's take on retelling their classic 1991 animated feature in a live-action version. Introducing an all new cast but familiar beats, and with a perfect blue-print to follow, does this version recapture that of it's predecessor?

1. First and foremost, if you are a fan of the 1991 film, you must try your best to see this film with an open mind. Although the plot in the same and the story unfolds the exact same way, there are still changes and different variations of things here and there. Everyone's main complaint is the look of the Beast (Dan Stevens). I would agree that he should have more of a vicious look, but the more I thought about it, if the original design of the beast from the animated film was translated into live-action, he would have been too terrifying and scare the daylights out of the younger audiences. In that sense, I can see why Disney altered him to be more subtle in appearance for that reason.

2. Alan Menken (the veteran Disney composer) returns to score this film, and he does yet another fantastic job in recreating his original songs for the new cast. The movie is approximately 120mins, and this can be in part to the addition of a couple new songs as well as more fleshed out back-stories, especially that of Belle and the Beast. Another complaint that crossed my ears, was the casting of Ewan McGregor as Lumiere, having been criticized for his shaky French accent judging by the trailers. Need not worry, you completely forget about your doubts when you see him on screen. Not only are the CGI effects fantastic, but Lumiere completely steals the show whenever he is on screen, especially during the "Be Our Guest" song and dance number.

3. The movie however, is not without flaws. To begin with, as beautiful as Emma Watson might be, she in no way captures the spirit of Belle. Coming to her father's rescue a couple times doesn't quite sell the point that she is as brave and courageous as she's supposed to be. She only skims the surface of the character without bringing much depth to it at all. Dan Steven as the 'Beast' however, shows more conviction in his role as the cursed Prince. His persona and feeling of a tortured soul comes closest to that of Robby Benson who voiced the Beast in the original. Sharing (a little but not as bad) the same lack of character depth as Emma Watson, Luke Evans (to me) feels slightly miscast as the handsome yet egotistical Gaston.

4. I applaud Bill Condon's direction as I was blown away by every theatrical song/dance sequences in this film. Of course the most outstanding being the classic ballroom scene which brought tears to my eyes. I also appreciate that the Beast finally gets to perform his own solo song which expressed his inner struggle of both anger and compassion. Something which was clearly missing from the animated film. There is no arguing with Disney especially when it comes to their CGI department, because they can do no wrong. The production design in beyond incredible with not a hair out of place. The magic is surely recaptured whether you admit it or not. This and 'The Jungle Book' surely stand out in Disney's live-action line-up thus far.

Fans will undoubtedly nitpick this film as much as they can simply because the animated one is sheer perfection in their eyes. Not saying it's not, but it be unwise not to give this version a chance, because it does it's best and delivers beat for beat in a spectacular way:)

title: Beauty and the Beast
review: The 1991 original Disney cartoon was the first full-length animated film to be nominated the Oscar for Best Picture, and following from Alice in Wonderland, Cinderella and The Jungle Book it becomes the next Disney classic to get the live action remake treatment, directed by Bill Condon (Gods and Monsters, Chicago, Dreamgirls). Basically somewhere in France, an enchantress disguised as an old beggar woman asks a selfish prince (apparently named Adam) (Downton Abbey's Dan Stevens) for shelter and offers a rose in exchange, he refuses and turns her away twice, she reveals her true beauty, but for his arrogance she punishes the prince, transforming him into a hideous beast, all his servants are turned into living inanimate objects, and all memory of the kingdom is erased from the memories of the villagers. His only way to see the outside world is through a magic mirror, and the enchanted rose remains, to break the spell the prince must learn to love another, and earn their love in return, before the last petal of the rose falls, or he will be doomed to remain a beast for all time, and the servants will become their respective objects forever. Years later, in the village of Villeneuve, Belle (Emma Watson) is the beautiful but unusual daughter of artist and tinkerer Maurice (Kevin Kline), she is appalled by the arrogance and narcissism of celebrated former soldier Gaston (Luke Evans), who seeks her hand in marriage. On a trip to the market to sell music boxes, Maurice and his horse Philippe get lost in the forest, following an attack by wolves, they finds the secluded castle of the Beast, Maurice ends up locked in a chamber as a prisoner, for attempting to steal a rose, for Belle, from the garden. Belle realises her father is missing, she ventures into the forest and finds the castle, the Beast confronts her, she offers herself to take her father's place as a prisoner, the Beast accepts this, and Maurice is released, Belle promises her father she will find a way to escape. Belle meets and becomes friends with the servants of the castle, including candle stick formed Lumière (Ewan McGregor), carriage clock formed Cogsworth (Sir Ian McKellen) and teapot formed Mrs. Potts (Emma Thompson). Wandering the castle she finds the forbidden west wing, and the enchanted rose, the Beast is enraged, Bell frightened runs away, the Beast saves her from an attack by the wolves, and when he is injured during the fight, she assists him back at the castle and nurses him back to health. Belle and the Beast form a friendship, and the servants are convinced she may be the one to help break the curse, the Beast allows her access to the library, filled with hundreds of books, she may be developing feelings, but remains uncertain due to her imprisonment. The Beast shows Belle a gift given to him by the enchantress, a book that takes a person wherever they want in the world, Belle uses it to take herself and the Beast to a small house in Paris, where she used to live with her parents as an infant, through this she learns her Mother (Zoe Rainey) died of the plague, the Beast comforts her. Meanwhile Maurice has returned to Villeneuve, the villagers believe him to be crazy, ranting about a beast, but Gaston offers to help him, but reveals his true intention is to marry Belle, Maurice refuses. Gaston leaves Maurice tied up in the forest to die, but he is rescued by hermit Agathe (Hattie Morahan), he returns to village and openly accuses Gaston of his crime, but Gaston convinces the townsfolk this is more crazy ramblings, they plan to send Maurice to an asylum. Belle and the Beast have become much closer, sharing a romantic dance, but she discovers her father's predicament using the magic mirror, the Beast allows her to leave to save him, he gives her the mirror to look back and remember him with, the Beast realises he truly loves Belle. At Villeneuve, Belle proves Maurice's sanity by revealing the Beast in the mirror, Gaston realises she has feelings for the Beast and rallies the villagers to go to the castle and kill the Beast, Belle and Maurice are locked in a wagon. During the ensuing fight at the castle, Gaston's companion LeFou (Josh Gad) sides with the servants when Gaston abandons him, the Beast is initially to depressed to fight back, but Gaston attacks the Beast, the Beast regains his will seeing that Belle has returned, he corners Gaston, but spares his life. The Beast reunites with Belle, but Gaston fatally shoots him, before falling to his death as a bridge collapses, the Beast dies as the last rose petal falls, and all servants are turned into their respective objects. Belle professes her love to the Beast, Agathe watching reveals herself as the enchantress and breaks the curse, the Beast is returned to human form, and the servants and castle are restored to their true forms, also the memories of the villagers are restored, with some recognising the servants, the prince and Belle embrace, and everyone in the kingdom dances happily. Also starring Stanley Tucci as Maestro Cadenza, Audra McDonald as Madame Garderobe, Nathan Mack as Chip, Gugu Mbatha-Raw as Plumette, Gerard Horan as Jean the Potter and Adrian Schiller as Monsieur D'arque. Watson is beautiful and sings well, Stevens is good as the Beast, Evans milks the pantomime style villain, and the supporting cast are great as well, it follows primarily the same format, with only subtle changes, the recognisable songs remain, including "Be Our Guest", "Something There" and "Beauty and the Beast", plus great brand new songs, including the wonderful "Evermore", the costume design, production and special effects are brilliant, and the love story element is believable, it may be more style over substance, but all of the family will definitely enjoy it, it is a most entertaining musical romantic fantasy. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Costume Design and Best Production Design, and it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Costume Design and Best Production Design. Very good!

title: I love it, but it's not really perfect
review:
*** THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***

Well, i love this movie to be honest. You know, my lovely Lumiere, Cogsworth, Mrs. Potts, Chip, etc are real! They're real and its magical. I know it using a lot of CGI, but that's no problem. title: A beautifully nostalgic movie
review: The live action version of Beauty and the Beast is a remarkable movie, with a lot of roses blooming with every scene played out. The cast was spot on, the VFX was remarkable, the music was nothing short of brilliant and the nostalgia was just right. This movie cannot be of course compared to the original because as I said, it stands out from its original material and delivers its own magic. It re-freshens the story with an incredible soul and a heart that is beastly in its grandeur, humor, romance and nostalgia.While some of the critics view Disney as playing off of our nostalgic senses and giving us "a mediocre, poorly made movie", I disagree wholeheartedly. This movie is more than just a nostalgic call to when the original movie came out and how perfect it is. Yes, nostalgia plays a part in it but at the end of the day, this new live action version stands on its own and delivers a strong performance worthy of the effort put into making it. The feelings I got when I first watched the original were a major part in why I went to see the movie – and why others will too – but that's because nostalgia is all man needs nowadays; to remember that beauty lies within. Kudos to the art direction team behind the sets in the Beast's Castle! They manage to create an architectural wonder by mixing whimsically dizzying features to the castle with the brooding, Gothic atmosphere that seems to loom over the snow/ice covered grounds. The Castle is a portrayal of the darkness and despair that seem to have a hold on the Beast's heart, adding more depth into the structure of the Castle. Alan Menken, who won an Oscar for the score of the original Beauty and the Beast, was back to add his charm, expertise and soul into the music behind the movie. For those of you who are familiar with the music, it is pretty much the same as the original one which was already super perfect. The songs have been executed quite nicely with three new songs added as a tribute to the late Howard Ashman, whose work on the Beauty and the Beast Soundtrack is just phenomenal. While we were expecting Belle to woo us with her singing or at least Emma Thompson with her warmth, we were delightedly surprised with Dan Stevens' deep tenor- like vocals. This was the only scene in the entire movie that I was dreading would be horribly executed and instead, I had tears rolling down my cheeks with a big fat smile on my face. The iconic yellow dress (which was altered from the original and meant to show how different this century's Belle is), the ballroom, the song sung by Emma Thompson, the dance itself; it was just made perfectly. The atmosphere of the dance, knowing that the Beast was hoping that this would be the night he would tell her how he feels about her; again, just perfect! Also, a huge nod to the creative team behind the "Be Our Guest" sequence; it was magical! That scene brought tears to my eyes as well: it was colorful, dizzyingly dazzling, filled with spirit, laughter and brought me back to the essence of the original "Be Our Guest". I was singing it out loud in the movie theater.

title: Simply stunning
review:
I will start out by saying that I am a Disney lover! As soon as I heard that they were remaking this I was extremely excited! After watching once I will have to watch again to decide which version I like more.

The story line followed the Disney original incredibly well adding in only a few minor details which I personally think enhanced the movie. Beautiful animation, fantastic acting, overall I was incredibly pleased. I look forward to adding this to my movie collection.

title: slightly above average
review: Personally I loved the movie. The CGI of Beast's face really wasn't THAT distracting. Sure, it didn't look the most lifelike but every movie has its flaws. Emma Watson was OK for the role of Belle. I didn't love her voice, but her acting was OK. She's better at portraying Hermione than Belle for sure. She wasn't as terrible as everyone is making her out to be. If you love Disney you will be able to look over the flaws and accept the movie the way it is made. It didn't have the heart wrenching roar from the Beast when Belle left, but it was replaced with something sadder. When everyone is turning into antiques Mrs. Potts is panicking trying to find Chip to see him one last time, but it's too late. Now, I am not one to cry during movies, especially in public, but I couldn't help shed a tear or two (or 50) The music was AMAZING. I watched the movie when it came out and I'm still listening to the soundtrack. The voices in Be Our Guest were spectacular. Overall it was a pretty good movie, but definitely not one of the best.

It did have few tear jerking moments, but not as you expect. Nevertheless it was a good movie and I love the small additional scenes which were not in the original Disney.

review: I really enjoyed it as did my mother, I brought my young son. He found the first half too scary. I really liked Emma in it. I do prefer the singing voices of the original though. I think all the acting was very good but overall film lacked that high level of magical feeling you get from the original animation

title: It hurts me to write this.
review:
'beauty and the beast' was my favorite Disney film and i cried at every single trailer they ever played. to say i was excited was an understatement. The movie was perfectly cast-FOR THE ORIGINAL. it's legitimately a line in the cartoon-'if it's not broke, don't fix it'. so why did we need to fix a perfect cartoon and make it a Politically correct family friendly movie? half of the beauty and charm of the cartoon original is that it really isn't for kids, at all. from Gaston's chauvisnistic (but hysterical) lines, to an actual terrifying Beast, toning it down was a major mistake. However, that may be casting's fault so let's break it down. Emma Watson was the perfect Belle. I was a little worried when they said they were making her a pro-active princess, as she was already kick ass enough in the original and even more might make her obnoxious, but thankfully the changes were subtle. Luke Evans was a deliciously evil Gaston. Imagine how much more perfect he would have been had he would have been allowed to do what Gaston did in the original? and Josh Gad. a PERFECT Lefou, but let's be real. when you hear Josh Gad has been cast as Lefou, you look forward to two years down the line when he has to stand outside in the snow dressed like a snowman. erasing any trace of snow and rewriting LeFou's comedy was a HUGE mistake, as funny as he still was.

now, the mistakes. Dan Stevens was miscast as the Beast, unless he was intentionally supposed to be a softie. Robbie Benson's powerful voice in the original frightens you to death, while Stevens' portrayal makes you roll your eyes. maybe that was the point, i don't know, but i do know that by making both gaston and beast softer characters, it's not as much a competition for Belle. The rest of the cast was fine. you really can't go wrong with anyone and no one did anything to really make themselves stand out either.

Now, i will admit, this film still made me emotional. I cried from 'evermore' (A+ decision to add that song) until the end of the film, but i was still expecting more. when i watch the cartoon, i'm a mess from the moment the music starts. which brings me to the music. You can't go wrong with it in this film, and I noticed something a lot of others are pointing out: it is so NICE to have actors who ENUNCIATE and to finally know what the lyrics to the song are. i'm 31 and i found out i'm singing the songs wrong because the animation isn't as clear. LOL as for the changes made to the songs, again PC decisions. the new lyrics were fine, and funny, but like i said, much more for kids. we can show two guys dancing but we need to cut out 'and every last inch of me is covered in hair?'. AND ON THAT NOTE, the director was such an idiot for opening his mouth about that 'gay moment'. it was a point second of Lefou dancing with a man, something not common in those days. WHY EVEN SAY ANYTHING?

Overall, I still enjoyed the film, I just can't give it the 10/10 i give the animation.

title: A classic retelling of a popular classic
review: I remember watching the animated 1991 film and hearing Angela Lansbury who played Mrs. Potts in the film sang the wonderful song beauty and the beast which is this time around sung by Audra McDonnell. I will say Emma Watson was great as belle since she looks the part and has a great singing voice. Josh gad was hilarious as Lefou the sidekick of the vain gaston who is gay in this version which brought up lots of controversy. I will say while it stays faithful to the animated film, but I will say that it was rather dark.

title: Disney can still work the magic even out of the animation studio, and 26 years later after a treasured classic.
review:
Bill Condon (Dreamgirls, The Fifth Estate, and Mr Holmes) re-invents the wonderfully powerful fantasy tale of Beauty and the Beast, continuing Disney's mission to make live action versions of their classic films. Re-introducing the lovely story of love and beauty that we all treasure, Disney have created a fine piece of work that reminds us of our passion for the story.

As we all know Belle (Emma Watson) is a intelligent girl a head of her time, who is snatched from her ordinary life, into the mysterious world of the Beast (Dan Stevens), when her farther is taken kidnapped by him and she takes his place. But as she discovers the secrets of the Beast's castle and furniture she and the Beast find something that wasn't there before. See what I did? In a visually magnificent presence, the story we love is moved pleasantly onto the live action screen in a colourful and enjoyable experience. Of course not replacing the original masterpiece, the film has its own merits as its own re-telling. These new live action films are not here to replace our memories but show them in the real world instead of animation. I hold that the same magic is equally qualified but with the advancements of technology in filmmaking, the magic that animation could only portray can be seen in real life form.

Emma Watson is the perfect Belle, with no other actor coming to mind to replace her, with her lovely appearance and character fuelling and taking lead of her performance, Watson is an absolute pleasure. Dan Stevens apparently taking the role of the Beast but is too layered in CGI and voice adaptors to tell its him, but somehow making perfect sense when his flesh self is seen. Not forgetting the jewel of the story but the living furniture of Lumière (Ewan McGregor) Cogsworth (Ian McKellen), Mrs Potts (Emma Thompson), all shinning still amazingly all the household appliances that we'd love to own.

Luke Evans steals the show as Gaston , really showing off his self centred, boasting character combined with the humorous match of Josh Glad as LeFou, who's secret is clear but barley as shocking as claimed.

What can be said about Beauty and the Beast (2017) is that a it is a very justified and fine reminder of why we love Beauty and the Beast (1991). Not to say that its not good on its own, on the contrary it is a very enjoyable delight with its majestic music sequences that captures the magic perfectly. But its just not the Disney classic.

The film has added its own additions and side bits, which unfortunately bring very little to the film and could be removed with no difference but are still perfectly fine anyway. At times I couldn't help but look at the film and think that's it was very set piece-y and not as real as it would like to be. Personally I thought I was watching a theatre play at moments.

The Beauty and the Beast song remains as indestructible as ever, but is challenged by Emma Thompson's slightly over sold accent, but does not stir away from the magic. By the end of the film you re-discover the power and love of the story.

At the end of the day, Beauty and the Beast is a wonderful experience that I'm sure will be enjoyed, but just won't match the power of the original, and sometimes too loud in its scenery but none the less an absolute delight. 7.5

title: Beauty and the Best 2017
review: Is a really good movie I starting watching it on Netflex is better then the first one that I been watched on video tape am waiting for part 3 I like it is fun

title: La La Land flatness and just too long.
review: Finally caught up with this on DVD today, I also caught up with La La Land this week and both left me with the same feeling of flatness. Something just didn't work, there were nice songs nice scenery, etc but no joy, no light in Belle's voice and no light in her eyes. I felt that in the very first song in the village she came across as a complainer, and a bit of an "I'm too good for these peasants" feel, rather than just the restlessness of the original Belle. It was unfortunate but this impression tainted the way I responded to her for most of the movie. I also couldn't believe the flatness of her reaction to the Be Our Guest song; where was the amazement, the joy etc, she just came across as "oh this is nice". I also felt it inappropriate of Disney to introduce a homosexual element to the story, this is a film for kids for goodness sake, get over yourselves and your agendas and stick to great storytelling and let our children enjoy their childhood without your issues getting in the way. But there were some very enjoyable moments, the snow fight, the library scene, the dance and the final battle between villagers and the castle crew were all very good. I just wish they'd found a different actor to play Belle and left out some of the junk and cut the length down, it was just too long for kids.

title: Stockholm Syndrome: The Movie
review: Beauty and the Beast should be called Stockholm Syndrome: The Movie. It loses a lot of its whimsy and becomes slightly creepy in its premise in live action format (which it's not so much live action as it is Hermione staring with wonder at a fixed spot as stuff happens later in post production) and the timeline in how far the castle is from the town and when things happen are all kinds of screwed up in editing. title: You better go watch it right now
review:
You wouldn't think that 'tales as old as time' would need so much retelling but they do. Certain properties never go away or are open to constant reinterpretation like the Shakespeare oeuvre or, well, fairy tales. A cursory bit of research reveals that there have been at least a dozen feature films or TV series from various countries based on Beauty and the Beast tale.

If you have never existed before today, here's what you need to know: A cruel prince is cursed and transformed into a beast. If the Beast doesn't learn to love and be loved in return by the time the last petal on a magic rose falls, the curse will become permanent. Enter a beautiful girl who could be the one to break the spell.

title: Compared to the original it's awful but it's entertaining nonetheless; Would Recommend
review:
Directed by Bill Condon

Starring Emma Watson, Dan Stevens and Luke Evans

Plot Overview: ​After her father is kidnapped and held hostage in a mysterious castle, Belle(Emma Watson) takes his place but soon begins falling for her captor... a beast(Dan Stevens)!

I get the hate for this movie. Nothing exceeds the original and the original will be marked as an all time classic. If you compare both these movies side by side, this movie will suck, I promise you that. Despite that, this movie is still entertaining. Flawed? Yes. Outright awful? No. It has its flaws, nearly every movie does, but that doesn't take away from some of the good in this movie. If you haven't seen the original(I recommend you do) I imagine you'll enjoy this movie for the most part. If you have seen the original and are going to constantly compare this movie to that, then you won't enjoy this movie. Overall, I will say this movie is worth watching, and I imagine most audiences(especially children) will really enjoy this movie. Also, if you prevent your child/refuse to see this movie because of the alleged Le Foue gay controversy then you have nothing to worry about. They gloss over it is seconds and it won't bother you at all.

The story is a 'tale as old as time' but that doesn't make it any less magical, exciting and enjoyable. It's pretty much the story of the original with a few tweaks here and there so if you've seen the original, you'll know the story and won't be surprised(much) but if you haven't then you'll get to experience a wonderful story for the first time in live action. Either way, it's a good story.

I will say that most of the casting in this movie is absolutely flawless. Emma Watson was fine as Belle but she isn't the best singer and when she is, it's clearly been heavily edited. They explore Belle's character more in this version which I will say was pretty nice and a welcome inclusion. Dan Stevens was great as the Beast but I do feel like he could have put more care into some of his scenes and not rushed things. There were many scenes that should have had greater meaning and effect but didn't, and that was down partly to Steven's portrayal but mostly down to Condon's direction. I also didn't like the arc of the Beast and though it was primarily just a straight line with no curves or edges. Luke Evans was just fantastic as Gaston and plays the part to perfection. He made the role his own and was easily one of the best parts of this movie. Gaston is also just a really great villain. He's awesome. You can't mention Gaston without his buddy Le Foue(played wonderfully by Josh Gad) who has had some tweaks to his character and arc(some of which stupidly garnered controversy) all of which I like and am happy Disney went with. Both Ewan McGregor and Ian McKellen were great as Lumiere and Cogsworth respectively and both their characters stood out for me. Kevin Kline was also really good as Maurice and the relationship between him and Belle was explored more and was another welcome improvement.

On a technical standpoint, this movie is absolutely gorgeous and looks amazing. The visual effects were all awesome, even if I would have done the Beast a tad differently. Both the costume and set design were all really good and looked nice with the time period. The cinematography was also amazing.

While this movie made some minor changes, it didn't add/remove/alter enough for me to say a sequel was needed or warranted. It was reasonably funny but some of the jokes were clearly aimed at the lowest possible denominator. It did need to reintroduce this classic tale to children of this age but some of the kids in my audience were crying and even I was pretty shocked by how graphic some scenes were(as far as making the audience scared goes) and scare factor of some scenes. The action was amazing though and it didn't even need to be that great.

They do carry over much of the music from the original(while adding new songs) but none of them are done as well as in the original and none of them were performed to a spectacular degree.

In conclusion, if you can ignore the existence of the original you will most likely enjoy this movie. The acting is great, the story is great, the visuals are gorgeous but it does lack some of the charm and sense of wonder that the original did posses. Despite this, I can say I recommend this movie as long as you can forget the existence of the 1991 Classic.

7/10

Would Recommend

title: The Iconic Rose Drops the Mic
review:
The "little town" and "quiet village" have jumped to worldwide fame. With a fantastic cast and a well-loved original, expectations raised to breaking point. My favorite parts of this remade fantasy, which successfully combined the old plot with new elements, were the excellent singing and the believable romantic relationship.

I hardly ever cry at movies, but I did during Beauty and the Beast. The songs -"Belle," "Beauty and the Beast," and "Something There," to name a few - powerfully resonate with the beautiful voices of the well-chosen cast members. The song "If I Can't Love Her" was especially moving as the Beast frees Belle and watches her run away.

I was really glad that the bond between Beauty and the Beast seemed to form a real relationship. In the old movie, it almost seems that they avoid one another and they do not talk much. In the remake, they seem to really get along together and boost each other up: the beast takes Belle to her old home and grants her freedom, and Belle reads to the Beast and nurtures him back to health.

Sometimes the conversations in the movie seem a little stilted and awkward. However, the overall connection between Beauty and the Beast overcomes these brief moments, and it is believable that both would risk death for the other. With high-quality music, casting, animation, character roles, and acting, this movie concocted a brilliant performance at which anyone would love to "be a guest."

title: Another Review
review:
First, LOL because the hundreds of user reviews are mostly negative and their main gripe was it was either too much or too little like the animated version. Yes, apparently it can be both.

This movie is a good adaption. I repeat for the half of the public who have the comprehension of a potato: it's an adaption of the fairy-tale--not intended to be a copy of the animated film. It included the classic elements of the animated film as to be a tribute and enough originality to be memorable and stand on its own. The depth of the story line is phenomenal.

I was surprised to see almost the same objections in so many reviews that lead people to dislike the film so to be fully prepared, you will be disappointed if you compare things like:

-More emotion or expression. The household objects faces won't be as animated as the cartoon. The characters (Belle, Beast, etc.) won't be as dramatic/emotionally expressive as the animated film

(it's not a Broadway play and the animated film was supposed to be dramatic bc it's a kids movie) -The Beast's eyes to look CGI (good news--they're actually Dan Steven's eyes)

I actually enjoyed this live-action more than the 1991 film. The CGI wasn't perfect (but it was good) and I missed the voice of Angela Lansbury, but the ballroom dance scene was the only one which could have met a higher expectation (maybe it needed more film angles). Also, one of the main wins for the script was making the beast appear more a human trapped as a beast (He felt like a person--even the same person in his beast or man form). Overall, wonderful movie.

title: A Wonderful Adaption
review:
I have been wondering while listening to the reviews of this latest version of Disney's Beauty and the Beast how many of the critics panning it are Millennials who were kids when this came out and have been spoiled by the era of CGI. I was an adult when that film came out but loved it anyway. The 1991 version was a leap forward in Animation with its use of computer produced art and the more intimate storytelling that was only seen before in moments of The Little Mermaid.

When they said Disney had turned it into Broadway Musical I wasn't surprised because that is essentially what this is. It's a Menken/Ashman (with some help from Tim Rice) musical of which the 1991 film was simply one version. Menken and Ashman both treated it that way and the film was all that better for it. If you look at it from that perspective the why of redoing it can be answered. Like any other well- loved musical doing it again with a different cast and director will always be something people will want to do. I think it's time to see this for a new generation.

This is a visually stunning film. The CGI of the Beast was only distracting in the beginning but once you got connected to the performance that Dan Stevens gives it no longer matters. Like the 1991 version the colors in this film are vivid and bold. The set decoration and costuming are lavish and beautiful. The character design of the household objects is amazingly detailed. The film hearkens back in some ways to musical extravaganzas of the 50s and the 60. The "Belle" sequence reminded me of the film version of the Oliver musical. The "Gaston" sequence had moments that reminded me of Seven Brides for Seven Brothers and when Emma Watson sings "Belle (Reprise)" reminded me of Sound of Music. The end titles even had nod to the same genre.

The musical numbers were very well done particularly the rendition of the "Gaston". Of the new musical numbers "Evermore" and "How Does a Moment Last Forever" were beautiful and fit well into the new version. Emma Watson did a very good job as Belle. While her voice is not Broadway quality is sweet and charming. I think Autotune has been imagined on it because the media has told people it was there in the trailers. Dan Stevens as the Beast is very powerful and manages to give Beast life under all the CGI. The supporting cast (especially Luke Evans, Josh Gad, Ewan McGregor, and Emma Thompson) are all very good. The cast doing the voice parts also infuse life into their characters with their vocal performances. Despite his concerns about his French accent McGregor did a brilliant job with his role. Emma Thompson gave a pleasant rendition of "Beauty and the Beast".

While the film is reverent to the 1991 film it should be taken as its own entity. I highly recommend this film for family viewing. It is a beautiful, joyful experience.

title: If it ain't broke, don't fix it
review:
This is the Bill Condon adaptation of the Disney animated classic from 1991. Let me repeat that this is a live action adaption OF A CLASSIC! I have read many reviews complaining about its lack of originality but im here to say that why would we want to change a story that is so dear to many a heart. This movie is a fantastic viewing for children and adult alike. though i recognize that it is not perfect.

The acting roles were also done masterfully but with some questions in my humble opinion. i thought everyone except emma watson as belle fit perfectly. ESPECIALLY GASTON! Luke evans stole the show for me. a big surprise was josh gad as lefou because it was brilliant. josh gad did a great job. all voice acting was superb and made it grand to be a guest for their show.

this movie holds dear to the story while also adding depth to pretty much all the characters and even surprisingly giving depth to LeFou. Some songs have been added which definitely did add to the story beautifully. This movie feels very much like a musical due to the increase of songs within the movie so it does feel like they sing way more then in the animated.

This movie was a very satisfying cinematic experience with breath taking visuals from the beast to the castle and everything in between. sets were absolutely gorgeous and every shot of this movie is a beautiful master piece. and equally as beautiful is the heart that is added through background stories mainly of beast and learning more about belles mother which we learn very little about in the animated.

overall this movie was an awesome viewing for me being a whole life fan of the animated classic and i feel this only made it even better by adding more to love that fits so perfectly. it is a beautiful viewing so go see it.

title: A very pleasant experience
review:
If you loved the original animated film or if you love the Broadway production, then I think you'll end up enjoying this production as well. One thing I really liked is that this film provided some more backstory on the curse and filled in some spots the original never made clear. The cast is also very good and they fit their roles well. The singing is also good. Emma's voice isn't as strong as the others but it was nice anyway. And of course the costumes were beautiful (although not as outstanding as Cinderella was). But the production design was gorgeous and would be a shame if it didn't get an academy award nomination next year.

With a couple of minor changes, it does pretty much follow the route as the animated movie practically beat for beat. Although one change I thought was kind of unnecessary/silly was making the Belle the inventor. Its not like it added anything to the story or having Maurice be an artist add anything different but they also barely even focused on it. They show her make one thing and its never referenced again. Not even in Beast's castle is she seen working on something. At least in the animated movie, it served a purpose by making the townspeople already think of Maurice as kind of kooky (and therefore unbelievable when he comes back to tell them of the beast). Plus, one of his inventions actually helps Belle escape from the basement. Here, it literally doesn't add anything.

I saw it in a theater with a bunch of kids present and I heard giggles of delight from them, so I think it will be a hit with them. Overall, I enjoyed it.

title: A gorgeous adaptation of the animated film
review:
Disney's latest live-action adaptation is the musical romance, Beauty in the Beast. Using stunning and gorgeous special effects, the story of Belle (Emma Watson) and her imprisonment by and growing affection for the Beat (Dan Stevens) plays out in the same way as the cartoon. A selfish prince is cursed by an enchantress and everyone in his castle is turned into fancy objects. Belle finds herself in a small town gossiped about by the villagers and wooed by the crude hunter Gaston (Luke Evans). Belle's father Maurice (Kevin Kline) is an inventor hoping to sell his wares at the market when he becomes lost in the woods and stumbles upon the enchanted castle. He is imprisoned by the Beast but his horse returns to Belle who seeks out her father.

Belle trades places with her father but is let out of her cell by the mouthy candlestick Lumiere (Ewan McGregor). The cautious clock Cogsworth (Ian McKellen) does not support the idea but Mrs. Potts (Emma Thompson), her son Chip (Nathan Mack), the dresser Madame Garderobe (Audra McDonald), and Maestro Cadenza (Stanley Tucci) are friendly to Belle and encourage the Beast to talk with her. They romance starts slow but in time their affection grows. Meanwhile, supported by his friend LeFou (Josh Gad), Gaston continues his plan to wed Belle by trying to win over her father who spouts outrageous stories of the Beast capturing Belle. Gaston does not believe him and they are unable to discover the castle.

Check out more of this review and others at swilliky.com

title: Directorial Letdown for film with many strong elements
review:
A solid B. Which is slightly disappointing considering the original film is an A+ classic nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars. Much of the script was reworked and rewritten for this new version, many of what I feel are the most powerful and memorable bits of dialogue were reworded and lost their power in the process. On the other hand, this film added a lot of background action and backstory to nearly all the characters (even adding a few new characters) which brought a lot of life to the production, certainly helping to flesh out the Beast and his servants in particular, though even Gaston, Maurice, and Belle got more to work with.

To my surprise, none of the performances stuck out as bad. Though Watson looked a little tentative during the earlier musical numbers, she delivered a fine performance through to the end of the film (though I found myself hoping she'd be more feisty like her animated counterpart). Dan Stevens as the Beast was a revelation, adding humor and depth to the character. While I thought when listening to the soundtrack that most of the new songs were dreadful, the new showstopper "Evermore" was beautifully executed by Stevens and became one of the most effective moments of the movie. Luke Evans made a marvelous Gaston, Josh Gad created a shockingly multilayered LeFou, and Ewan McGregor was pitch perfect as Lumiere. The funniest moments of the film easily went to Gad, Stevens and Ian McKellen, who played Cogsworth.

My biggest complaint is the noticeable absence of the joyous, brilliant "Human Again" number written for the original film, cut, added to the subsequent Broadway production, then re-edited back into the film. Instead, it was replaced by a rather sad sounding song called "Days in the Sun" with effectively the same theme.

Overall, my problem was neither with the actors or the design (which was stellar; I could have gazed at the detail on the set for days), but with the writing and directing. Whose idea was it to make Audra McDonald do an Italian accent, making all the wardrobe's lines clunky and unfunny? Most of the new songs don't hold a candle to songs written for the original film or the Broadway production. Belle and Maurice's new backstory felt oddly placed and a tad contrived. Given all this new material, it would have been fun to see director Bill Condon take some risks, but they never came. Even the way certain scenes were shot seemed uninspired. I enjoyed a great deal of the new material, I loved the life it breathed into the supporting characters, but they should have either gone all the way with it or not done it at all. Most distracting is that the Beast was done digitally rather than with makeup - it took you right out of the famous supposed-to-be-stunning dance scene. Stevens was on set acting with dots on his face, offering eyelines, and delivering a great performance. It's a shame they felt they couldn't do it practically.

title: Amazing experience for us Disney fans!
review: For a huge Disney fan like me, this movie was truly amazing to watch! The story (compared with the movie from 1991) had its' own touch with some totally new scenes which added a even more deep touch but still, as a fan, I could see many, many similarities between the both. Several lines were identical to the original and so was the way many scenes were cut. Lovely details only we who have seen the original a multiple times could notice. The music was great but I did not really enjoy the new songs. It felt a bit too much with so many songs and it would totally be enough with just all the old ones and maybe one or two new at most. Still, I got a great music experience and with the help from the breathtaking scenery I even shed some tears to the songs "Belle" in the beginning and the main theme "Beauty and the Beast" later in the movie. Emma is doing a great job and I think she is totally perfect for the role as Belle. So is Dan Stevens as the beast and I'm really impressed of their work! This movie is really good on its own but for us fans it's even more than that. From the story, scenery, music and the great actors we really get the right feeling from the 1991movie and that is an experience worth 10/10.

title: SPOILER ALERT -- I'm going to talk about events in the film, don't read if you don't want to know
review:
Absolutely gorgeous! I have no complaint about the cast, the sets, or the CGI -- it all worked for me.

Among my favorite parts of the film were the little salutes to various musicals as well as other Disney films. By my count there were salutes to:

Oliver!- Sound of Music-Singing in the Rain- Moulin Rouge

The whole "Be My Guest" is a feast of Busby Berkeley routines with a little Esther Williams thrown in.

I'm hoping to see the film up for several Oscars: Cinematography, Best Score, Costuming, Set Design, Make-up, and "Evermore" for Best Song, although I can see either "Days in the Sun" or "How Does A Moment Last Forever" being picked instead.

I loved the film so much I'm going back to see it again...maybe more than once.

Note: This film can be very dark, I would not take a very young child to this.

title: Be our guest? Certainly!
review:
Over all, I was quite pleased with the movie. I was most impressed with Luke Evan's portrayal as Gaston and Ewan McGregor's portrayal as Lumiere. All of the other actors did a phenomenal job in their roles as well. I think that Dan Stevens was the perfect actor to play the role of Beast in his beastly form, but also as the Prince as well. As with all movies, I always think that something could have been filmed better, or an actor could have done more better. I felt the same thing about Emma Watson as Belle. She certainly is the perfect choice for such a role and there is now a whole new generation who are going to associate her as Belle instead of Hermione from Harry Potter. (Same with Dan Stevens I'm sure. There's a new generation that now knows him as Beast instead of Mr. Crawley from Downton Abbey). But I found Belle a tad-bit boring in this live action. One of the most significant things about Belle is that she is a big reader. She loves books, and this is one of the roots of her being an independent-minded young woman (aside from her being the only child raised by her father). I feel like they could have put some more emphasis on her love for reading as this is one of the primary attributes we notice about Belle's character in the animated version. Emma Watson, an outspoken Feminist herself certainly did an incredible job adding those things to Belle that are empowering otherwise.

Luke Evans' Gaston was one of the portrayals that really surprised me. I love it how he added a bit of a sly side to him whereas, in the animated version he's all 100% masculine and domineering kind of person, someone who always gets what he wants. The live action Gaston has the same masculine and cocky kind of attitude, but the sound of Luke's voice and how he acted him in the movie, I really felt added a good amount of slyness to his villainy. It really gave off that "evil parading itself as a prince" kind of feeling. Lumiere is the other character I was really impressed with. Lumiere has been my favorite character out of the whole story since I was little. I loved his rather more flamboyant, entertaining spirit. I also really loved it that they put more emphasis on his relationship with Plumette in this live action version. Lumiere certainly added a nice blend of refreshing entertainment in my opinion.

A lot of things have been said about Lefou, I read my fair share of outrage from people about him being a gay character. Lefou really reminded me of another character from a very different movie. Billy Breckenridge played by Jason Priestly in the movie Tombstone. I certainly didn't have any issues with that, and I think that Lefou added a great deal of humor to the movie. My advise to the folks who are repulsed by Lefou's sexual orientation would be to re-watch the animated version as there are plenty of hints of his sexual orientation in that version. At the end of it all, it's really up to the person as to what they want to watch, what they want their kids to watch. However, I do promise you, if you chose to see this movie with your kids, they aren't going to notice anything out of the ordinary other than this is a good and fun movie.

Would I recommend this film to anyone? Certainly!

title: Amazing
review: I saw it opening day. This movie was great. Love the animated one grew up on it, didn't think this one would be as good because its just not the same as animation but it was incredible. everything from the characters/ Actors, music, wardrobe everything, defiantly a must see for everyone.

title: Confused by the negative reviews
review: Tasteful, true the original and very well cast. It didn't need to be a CGI fest, it's a classic Disney. Jungle Book had virtually none of the original songs which was a huge disappointed. It felt as though there was a respect for the film unlike other remakes. Of course people find some way to bash it but its an absolute masterpiece and should be enjoyed by all.

title: Perfect Adaption of the Original Cartoon
review: This is the best and the perfect adaption of the original cartoon in the 90s. It has some extension to the sound track and scenes, but they're there to build up the perfect emotion for viewers to fall in love with the characters. And I just must say that Emma Watson is truly the perfect selection to play as Belle. She's charming and just pure perfect! Ignore any bad reviews you see in here. If you liked the original cartoon, then you'll desperately fall in love with this one.

title: Had just as much charm, maybe more
review:
I don't understand the negative reviews. The criticisms I've read are trivial at best. This was a great movie. In fact, it was a perfect rendition of an all-time classic Disney movie. What made it so well- rounded was the fact that they stayed true to the 1991 original with a few added scenes that explained the story further.

It was a wonderful movie. Don't listen to these wannabe movie critics. Just go and enjoy.

title: Best Disney Remake Yet!
review: This movie was exceptionally great so a 10 in the ratings is a definite! The cast was great, the score was great, the acting was great, and the real life remake is surprisingly parallel to the original Beauty and the Beast. Emma Watson and Dan Stephens did not disappoint. Go see it! You won't regret it!

title: Did Original Justice, Despite Poor Direction
review:
I'll start by mentioning that I adore the original animation, rating it as my #1 Disney film. When I heard this was coming out, I was extremely excited. I had no idea what to expect and avoided the trailers because I wanted to keep an open mind - something that turned out to be very necessary!

First I'll start with a few weaker points.

The absolute killer for me was the general feel. It was nowhere near as vibrant as it should have been and I didn't feel enough contrast between the first and second halves. When I found out that the director of some Twilight films was involved, everything became very clear. At some points it just felt so grey and not very Disney-like and I truly think that poor direction held this production back. Especially some of the happier scenes in the castle - I was sitting thinking 'Jesus, isn't the saturation a little bit off'. I know it's supposed to be gloomy, but isn't the whole film really about finding beauty in unlikely places? That being said, the scene where Belle is racing through the gardens after being released was stunning.

Secondly the portrayal of a gay man for comic relief was distasteful and a little insulting. Props to Disney for having the guts to include this, however I can't help feeling that it was more for publicity than anything else. The whole thing with that musketeer being dressed as a woman was completely stupid and shortsighted; the same ridiculous clichè that the community tries so hard to cast off. If you're going to include a gay character, make it a full part of a story and not just comic relief or a fleeting scene obviously added to tick boxes. It was all quite irrelevant to be honest.

Lastly with the negatives - I didn't completely love the effects. I thought the cartoony feel was charming and not something I expected. Personally I felt this worked well - although the town felt more charming than anything else and I felt myself asking Belle, 'is it really that awful?'. On the other hand, it somewhat seemed a half-done job; halfway between an animation and live-play. The enchanted objects in the castle had really strange faces that didn't convey the comforting characters they're supposed to be but their bodies (for lack of a better word) were rather well animated. The Beast was a bit strange to look at too and felt half-baked. There was without a doubt, room for improvement there. The castle, however; was breathtaking and did the animated version the justice it deserved.

An area which I'm quite undecided on is Emma Watson as Belle. I adore her as an actress; I think she has some real talent but I can't work out whether she was right for the role. On one side she conveys the small-town girl role who wants adventure very well. Her inquisitive side is very believable and it's very clear she doesn't fit in. On the other side i don't really think she has the warmth of the original Belle; it was as if she cared more about rebelling and staying in the castle than about her feelings for the Beast. This is NOT a criticism of her acting at all - what she did, she did well despite the poor direction. I just believe there could have been a better fit.

Acting-wise the standout roles were probably Gaston and Lumiere's voice acting. They really carried the film in my opinion; Gaston was definitely more comedic than the original but this was a welcome addition. Lumiere was the perfect host and despite the questionable animation, was still the same charming character as before. I don't think any of the acting was particularly weak - still room for more believability but I blame the silly choice of directors - why choose the director of a cheap, wooden, gloomy series about vampires and werewolves for a vibrant Disney epic?

The film stays true to its roots and whilst it doesn't add much, what it did add worked really well. For example the book which took Belle back to Paris was something that really built upon her character, even if it was a little bit far-fetched. It answered some questions which were left unanswered before.

Something I really missed was the Beast's roar as Belle ran from the castle after letting her free. It's small, I know, but was incredibly powerful in the original. They could have saved themselves the effort of writing that extra song and portrayed the same pain.

Overall a good adaptation which somehow kept the charm of the original despite being held-back by poor choice of directors. Lots of room for improvement but certainly not a waste of time or money. Please also ignore these family-friendly negative comments. The 'gay' scene (it feels like a total joke even calling it this) lasted for probably not even a second and should have been cut anyway as it was totally pointless. Like I said, if you're going to include inclusive relationships, don't force it into a classic and do it properly! If girls were discouraged from reading and learning, I'd hardly expect anyone to be open- minded enough to accept a same-sex relationship.

title: Beautiful Retelling of a Classic
review: The only reason I did not give this film a 10 was because it does not surpass the original. This film is brilliant on so many levels. Kevin Kline, Emma Watson, Josh Gad, and Dan Stevens bring so much more depth to their characters and enhance the story we already love. Alan Menken adds some beautiful new pieces that add more emotion to the story. The few complaints I had with the movie were minor and didn't affect the real experience of the movie. Overall this is a great retelling of a classic with some modern twists.

title: Beauty & the Kevin Kline
review:

With that being said, he was the star of this film. He held it all together and if he wasn't present in the cast the movie would have fallen apart completely.

I haven't seen the movie yet but guys, it's Kevin Kline. I mean, he was in Wild Wild West AND No Strings Attached. Go see this movie. Pay $14 at AMC to see it IMAX 3D. I know I will. For Kevin.
